title: 111_hr2324
content: The Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2009 may be cited as the "Gun Show Background Check" act. The Congress finds that approximately 5,200 traditional gun shows are held annually in the US, attracting many attendees and firearms sellers. These shows provide a convenient location for criminals and prohibited persons to obtain firearms without background checks or traceable records. The term 'gun show' is defined as any event where 50 or more firearms are offered for sale, exchange, or transfer, excluding sales from an individual's personal collection at their private residence. This definition aims to regulate firearm transactions and ensure traceable records for gun tracing purposes. The term 'gun show' excludes sales, exchanges, or transfers of firearms by individuals from their personal collection at their private residence. Gun shows with less than 100 firearms offered for sale are exempt if conducted by hunting-focused not-for-profit organizations. Gun show vendors are individuals who are not licensed under section 923 and exhibit, sell, offer for sale, transfer, or exchange firearms at gun shows. These vendors are not required to arrange with the gun show operator for a booth. The text discusses the regulation of firearms transfers at gun shows, including the requirement for gun show operators to be at least 21 years old and the restrictions on unlicensed vendors selling firearms at gun shows. To operate a gun show, the person must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms across state lines, and must not have violated any firearm regulations. To operate a gun show, the person must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms across state lines, and must not have willfully violated any provisions of the chapter or regulations. The person must also register with the Attorney General, provide a photograph and fingerprints, and certify that they meet certain requirements. To operate a gun show, a person must meet certain requirements, disclose all material information, not make false statements, and pay a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. Gun show operators must comply with these regulations. Gun show operators must notify the Attorney General of key details before the show and verify the identity of vendors. Gun show operators must verify the identity of vendors by examining valid identification documents and having them sign a ledger with identifying information. Gun show vendors must enter identifying information into a ledger and receive a notice outlining their obligations under this chapter. Attendees must be notified of the requirements of this chapter. The Attorney General shall prescribe regulations for recordkeeping at gun shows to demonstrate compliance. Unlicensed persons are prohibited from transferring firearms at gun shows without a background check. Unlicensed individuals are not allowed to transfer firearms at gun shows without a background check. Licensed dealers must record firearm details and notify the parties involved in the transaction. Licensed dealers must provide information required by the Attorney General for transactions and notify parties about the unique identification number from the national instant criminal background check system. Recordkeeping requirements must be followed by the licensee. Licensed dealers must provide information required by the Attorney General for transactions and notify parties about the unique identification number from the national instant criminal background check system. Recordkeeping requirements must be followed by the licensee, including submitting a report of firearm transfers within 10 days to the Attorney General with specific details. The Attorney General requires licensed dealers to submit a report of firearm transfers within 10 days, excluding personal information of unlicensed individuals involved. The dealer must also retain transfer records as part of their permanent business records. Gun show vendors are not subject to additional recordkeeping requirements by the Attorney General. The Attorney General cannot impose recordkeeping requirements on gun show vendors. Penalties for violating specific sections include fines and imprisonment for up to 5 years. The penalties for knowingly violating section 932 include fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, and potential suspension or revocation of registration. After notice and a hearing, a person's registration under section 932(a) can be suspended for up to 6 months or revoked, with a civil fine of up to $10,000 imposed. The Attorney General may inspect gun show operators' records and inventory during business hours, as authorized by Section 923(g)(1) and Section 932(b)(2). The Attorney General may inspect gun show operators' records and inventory during business hours to determine compliance with the chapter, without needing reasonable cause or a warrant. Additionally, there are increased penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees at gun shows. The amendment to section 924(a)(3) of the title increases penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensed dealers, importers, manufacturers, or collectors who knowingly make false statements or violate section 922(m). Penalties include fines, imprisonment up to 1 year, or both. Increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements include fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both for offenses related to specific sections of the law. Increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements have been amended to include fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both for offenses related to section 922(t) of the law. Additionally, the authority to hire personnel to inspect gun shows has been granted to the Director. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives may hire additional personnel to inspect gun shows and must submit biennial reports to Congress on firearm sales at these shows. The section requires reports on firearm sales at gun shows, including details on background checks and resources needed. It will take effect 180 days after enactment.
